ranking: #5 of 119 things to do in Braga
ranking_subcategory: #5 of 119 things to do in Braga
reviews/0/text: The entrance is only 2 Euros if you want to see the Catedral. The whole sight is 5 Euros. It is an amazing architecture and sight and is strongly recommended.
reviews/1/text:
Amazing Church Sé de Braga.
With a Nice Architecture and Painting. Very well done.
Nice photos and nice time expended
reviews/2/text: the church really has the wow factor was the highlight of my trip to braga its a must even if you are not into churches make an exeption and vist this mastery
reviews/3/text: This church is beautiful and unique in its history. It is the oldest cathedral in Portugal, being founded even before the establishment of Portugal as a country. You can find important tombs inside if you participate in the guided, which I highly recommend, since it will give you access to the private chapels and the area where the religious leaders meet. Our tour was given in English (Portuguese was also possible of course). For 5 euros, you can see the cathedral, chapels, and museum.
reviews/4/text: If angels and baroque don't put you off, don't miss the Cathedral. Amazing work. The visit of the Chapels and Coro Alto shouldn't be missed.
reviews/5/text:
22/6/22 - Wednesday late afternoon

We three middle aged Brits were staying in town three nights and this was on our list. One of us is against church or cathedral entrance fees so we split up. At around 3:30pm I bought the full €5 ticket whilst my friend bought just the Cathedral €2 ticket in the side street entrance to the cathedral complex. My ticket included a guided tour of the chapels and upper choir, scheduled at 4pm.

We both had a walk around the cathedral which is quite plain with the statues on stretchers for decorating and hauling around town during Santa Semana. The organ was the most impressive thing in the church though. My friend left and I waited for the tour.

A group of mainly Portuguese gathered and a guide took us through the complex to a series of very interesting chapels of various ages. Tiled walls, pigment decorated walls, tombs, a very wrinkly but undecomposed archbishop (it's a miracle apparently), florid walls, turkish influences, mum&dad statues above tombs, miracle fruits....

I was the only English speaker there so the guide patiently repeated everything personally to me in English whilst an apprentice listened in.

Up we went a few flights of stairs into the upper choir which was amazing! Two identical working organs were at the alter end of the rows of named seats of the choir. A 'clock' at the end was set at 3pm as that's when Christ was nailed to the cross.

Later we three rejoined and wandered round the free parts of the cathedral complex including the archbishop tombs and a chapel with lots of wax figures of heads, legs and arms....a local custom?

Altogether a very good value excursion, especially with the one to one commentary! 

The managers just really need to get rid of that rubbish euro paladin bin in the courtyard though…..
reviews/5/title: Great organ, good value combi ticket, plain interior but undressed statues ready for santa semana
reviews/6/text: Impressive facade and portal but it does seem to have been hemmed in somewhat bylater additions. Internal monuments are grand enough to be impressive without being oppressively so and detracting from the magnificence of the building itself.
reviews/6/title: Exterior slightly pinched in but a glorious interior.
reviews/7/text: The Cathedral of Braga was consecrated in 1089, about 54 years before Portugal became a country! As is the case in many historical buildings, renovation and rebuilding through the centuries result in a variety of different architectural styles. Today’s church is a mix of Gothic, Manueline and Baroque features. There is a nominal charge to visit the church, and it will cost you a few more euros on top of that for the chapels, high choir, and museum. Go for it! You can view the high choir with its elaborate gilt wood carving and double organs from the nave, and then you’ll wish you were up close. The Chapel of Glory and the Chapel of Kings, both dating to the 1300s, are equally stunning.
reviews/8/text: Extremely gorgeous Roman heritage! Outside and inside decorations of this cathedral are so fabulous! Highly recommend visiting!
reviews/9/text:
The Braga Cathedral was built on the foundations of an old market or Roman temple, and the walls of a later Paleo-Christian basilica.
Its best documented history dates back to the work of the first bishop, D. Pedro de Braga, and corresponds to the restoration of the Episcopal and this in the year 1070, of which few traces are preserved.
In the year 1128, a building with five chapels at the apse was started, which were partially destroyed by the earthquake in the year 1135.
In the year 1268 the works were still not completed. On the outbuildings of the former house of the “Cabido”, built at the beginning of the 18th century by Archbishop D. Rodrigo de Moura Teles, currently stands the Braga Cathedral Treasure-Museum.
In the 20th century, the tomb of the religious and stigmatized Sister Maria Estrela Divina, a center of great popular devotion, was placed next to the cloisters. His collection of Sacred Relics became famous, including the piece of a Mantle of the Holy Virgin Mary, in the Chapel of Relics. There are chests containing the bones of many saints, and the so-called Holy Ark is legendary, whose contents will be remarkable, and went out in procession in the past, on days of solemn feasts.
It has been classified as a National Monument since the year 1910.
reviews/10/text:
As the proverb says, Porto works, Braga prays, Coimbra studies, and Lisbon gets the money. Se de Braga and it's amazing museum proves at least the part of praying. An impressive building, with impressive history and a huge collection of objects and stories relevant for the religious character of Braga city.

The visit includes a guided part (conducted by a young lady, prepared to answer questions and tell interesting stories) and a you're on your own part (quite OK, as the exhibits have enough information in English). It is well worth the small entrance fee.
reviews/11/text: We enjoyed viewing the architecture and the vast contrast between the original Romanesque and later Baroque features. We were less impressed by the museum - largely unlabelled items - difficult to understand full significance/story.
reviews/12/text: Nice architecture. This church is in a street that is usually full of restaurants and shops but luckilñy almost everything was closed when i visited.
reviews/13/text: You are about to visit the oldest Roman Catholic Cathedral Church in Portugal! The "Sé Catedral de Braga" dates from the 11th century and has seen, along the years, many additions and restorations. Naturally, characteristics of different architectural styles are found: Romanesque, Gothic, Baroque, Moorish and Manueline! Visit the church, check its facade, main nave, chapels, baptismal font, high choir, organs, cloisters, awesome gilted engravings and traditional Portuguese tiles. And if time is not a constraint, do not miss its adjoining museum, completely renovated in 2007 to house the Cathedral's magnificent religious art treasure! Enjoy!
reviews/13/title: 900 years of history and religious life!
reviews/14/text:
Braga is so special with so much history. Loads of Roman buildings,,actually whole city is build on top of the Roman City
I was very impressed with the Cathedral, especially is wooden carved ceiling, the courtyard with Roman statues, with a Museum where you can see Cardinals outfits.
It also has an area where you'l find its a resting place for Cardinals
reviews/14/title: A relic with an interesting museum
reviews/15/text:
It is the oldest cathedral in Portugal. Personally I liked very little both inside and outside. Few things to see and the exhibition path badly organized. Only positive note is the beautiful main facade decorated with a large number of statues.

If you would like to see my tips just go to the following link: https://www.tripadvisor.it/Trips/92555137/The%20northern%20region%20of%20Portugal
reviews/15/title: Only positive note is the beautiful main facade
reviews/16/text: It is a Se, but the Murials made of the blue & white tiles are beeuatiful, Especially the walls upstairs. The entrance fee is 2 Euro, so it's ok. There are many rooms to discover. So see for yourself.
reviews/17/text:
It's not often a specific church's beginnings can be attributed to Saint James.  Or that Saint Peter of Rates was resurrected to be Braga's first bishop.  This church has a varied collection throughout history, with the first thing we noticed was the old smell.  The original structure dates from the 1000s, replacing a prior structure. 
 The main chapel from the 1300s.  The organ from the 1700s.  And a lot of history in between.  Most churches seem to have a specific theme or focus; in my opinion not this one, other than history itself.
reviews/18/text:
The Cathedral in Braga is nowhere near as ornate as some of the other churches and from the outside looks more like a fortress than a place of worship.

Individual entry fees are charged for almost all areas except the courtyard and some tombs or you can pay €5 to visit the entire church.

Personally I found it a bit underwhelming although it might have been more interesting if I had been prepared to pay the €5.
reviews/19/text:
I really likes the Sè in Braga, right in the heart of the old town. For €2 you can visit the cloisters, crypt and the cathedral itself. For €3 you can visit the museum but I didnt add that particular option.
The Cathedral is cavernous as you'd expect but still retains a homely and welcoming feel. I loved the banners hanging from the walls between the windows and the unbelievably intricate and decorative organ at the back of the nave. The altar is simple, but it has gorgeous stained glass windows flanking stand beautifully carved chorister chaurs.
Most if the visit will be spent at the gold gilted organ I suspect. It really has to be seen to be believed, as beautiful an organ as you ever will see with a beautifully painted ceiling above it.

reviews/0/text: To be honest there is nothing special about the arc and the door. It is a tourist attraction. You can just go and cost and take the moment.
reviews/1/text:
What we can say about Arco da Porta Nova ...
It is a good place to take a few photos and ejoy that time
reviews/2/text: It is on the way to/from Braga's train station and on a major pedestrian street. Each side is of particular interest.
reviews/3/text: Impressive arch through which you pass to get into the old town. Good as a photo opportunity and also as ameeting/orientationpoint.
reviews/3/title: Impressive and useful as a meeting point
reviews/4/text: Such an iconic monument and a meeting place for most tours to Braga. Apparently this gate gave rise to many sayings in Portuguese and Spanish such as if you leave a door or window open, you will hear "You must be from Braga" coz the this monument does not have a door to close. Also, admonishments such as "I will send you to the lower parts of Braga" (this monument is at the lower part of Braga) arose out of this monument as the lower parts of Braga at the time were seedy. A piece of history!
reviews/5/text:
The “Arco da Porta Nova” was one of the doors in the city walls, torn down in the year 1512, at the time of the Archbishop of Braga, D. Diogo de Sousa.
Its current appearance dates back to the year 1772, at the initiative of Archbishop D. Gaspar de Bragança, with a project by the architect from Braga, André Soares, at a historical moment when the city broke the old walls, expanding.
It has been classified as a National Monument since the year 1910. Next to it is a medieval tower, belonging to the Fernandina wall, and practically covered by the houses. Anyhow a nice attraction to see during your visit of the historical part of the city of Braga.
reviews/5/title: Visiting the historical part of Braga.
reviews/6/text: Very nice entrance to the center of the city. Is the first thing you see when you arrive from the train station.
reviews/7/text: At the end or at the beginning of the De Souto street, it all depends from which side you come is this nice Arc to stroll underneath.
reviews/8/text: My first of the old town when walking up from the train station was this lovely decorative arch. It spans the narrow road attached on both sides to elegant buildings. It certainly lets you know you are entering a beautiful part of town as the historic centre is indeed a gem.
reviews/9/text:
Looks nice
Not huge 
But shows way into old town street
Braga looks interesting 
Cheap place to visit and live apparently
reviews/10/text: The Arch of the New Gate is a few hundred metres from the Braga Train Station. Thus when you walk to the Braga town centre from the train station it is the first tourist attraction you see. The gate is the entrance, and part of the old wall, to Old Town Braga. It’s architecture is beautiful and a good welcome to your Braga visit experience.
reviews/11/text: It's at the doors of the city. You won't miss it. It's part of of the old walls! It gets you right on track to go to downtown. Take it as your pointing-guide.
reviews/11/title: You won't come to Braga without seeing this monument!
reviews/12/text: You know when you have happened upon this landmark, helps get you oriented on the tourist map and guide you to main street.
reviews/13/text: Part of the old entrance to Old Town. I found it interesting and a great marker when with a group. A must see if you are down town.
reviews/14/text: This arch is perhaps the best symbol of Braga's welcoming spirit. It was the first time a city wall had a permanently open door. Close to the end of the afternoon, walk down Rua do Souto and admire the golden reflex caused by the sunset in this monument. Admire it for a while and turn right, getting into Tíbias de Braga pastry. Choose anything. All items are excellent.
reviews/15/text: The Arch of the New Gate is a great entrance to the old city of Braga.  The front side is more decorative than the back side.  There are many restaurants just past the entrance and down the street on the left.
reviews/16/text: We had a meal in one of the restaurants near by when we saw the arc! Beautiful addition to our walk in town! Nice photo stop!
reviews/17/text:
The Arch was well worth visiting. We walked through the arch and along 
into the city centre. It was a lovely place to see.
reviews/18/text:
Didn't know that there was a gate here.
Make sure you check out both sides as they are different. 
In very good condition and marks the entry to the old town.
reviews/19/text: This entrance, the only one remaining, is quite impressive, and well worth the walk there, in this small historic town. There is no entrance fee, and cannot be climbed either).
reviews/19/title: Nice old entrance gate to a nice historic city

reviews/0/text:
Jardins da Casa dos Biscainhos is a great spot for someone who wants to take a few pictures.
We will be back here
reviews/1/text: It's a beautiful garden, with a lot of potencial for other activities that could better dinamize the space.
reviews/2/text: Jardim da Casa dos Biscainhos is just so lovely. The Gardens are really beautiful and obviously extremely well maintained. You enter and find yourself in another world, quiet, peaceful and restful. The residence is another lovely building and there are so many beautiful objects to admire.
reviews/3/text: You begin your visit of Biscainhos by viewing the gardens which are very pretty when the Camélia trees are in bloom. Then a guide takes you through each room of the palace which contains furnishings appropriate to the time period. Well worth a visit.
reviews/4/text:
Nice to go to and rest a bit. Gardens are free.
Average but if you have the time... why not?
If you have more time visit the house (pay 2 euros).
reviews/5/text: Lovely gardens, very quiet and peaceful. It's free! And a great place to relax a bit. I definitely recommend it.
reviews/6/text: Lovely house and gardens. Excellent guided tour of the house only at specific times. Beautiful interior and a garden to linger in.
reviews/7/text: This is a peaceful garden at the back of the casa dos biscainhos and well worth visiting. Some of the structures are closed but even on a cold wet day it was very attractive
reviews/8/text: Really lovely gardens behind the mansion.  Our visit was free.  Beautifully landscaped with some charming statues.  Good photo op.  Old world charm.
reviews/9/text: It's really worth visiting the museum that allows you to visit the house and gardens. It's in the city centre and cheap.
reviews/10/text: There are flowers here year round. It is a lovely place for a stroll or even a great place to sit and read up on the attractions in Braga. It is very well maintained and the colors can be stunning. Near the casa, inside the wrought iron fencing is part of an old Roman archway.You can get a very nice picture through the fence, if you are lucky, the roses will be blooming too.
reviews/11/text: Placed almost in the heart of the city and very easily missed this gardens are a real gem, very nice for a sunny afternoon spent in the middle of a little heart of nature, combined with a visit to the Museum makes it for a refreshing afternoon.
reviews/12/text:
This is where we stayed for a rest after our morning walk. We were looking and inquiring how to get a ride in going to Sanctuario Bom Jesus. Everyone was nice and helpful. 

Lovely garden and shady cool atmosphere.
reviews/13/text: We visited it as part of the house tour so I don't know if you can visit it separately (cheaper) but it's a beautiful garden
reviews/14/text: A great place to visit both during summer and in the winter and there is no entrance fee.. it's a shame they closed a little early in the evening
reviews/14/title: A great resting place in between tours
reviews/15/text: Loved this garden, you can get cool pictures here. You can imagine how crazy it must been to live here in past times.
reviews/16/text:
Well maintained with some good specimen trees. Not a lot flowering at the end of September but as it s free I will visit again in the Spring. 
While we were there a tour group came in and were done and out while we were still there.
We didn't go in the museum although did sneak in at the end of the tour to look at the kitchens which were interesting.
reviews/17/text: This is a beautiful garden in the Biscainhos Museum, in the center of Braga. The garden it's in barroco style, with many old trees.
reviews/18/text: If you are exploring the city it is well worth walking through the gardens and exploring this site. Well maintained.
reviews/19/text: The Garden is part of/hidden behind the Biscainhos Museum. It is at three levels with mature tress, flowers ponds and fountains which sadly were not working when we were there. Ornaments, shady paths, and a summer house all add to the experience.summer house

ranking_subcategory: #2 of 119 things to do in Braga
reviews/0/text:
Enjoy this excelent piece of art that worth a visit.
Take 1 hour for a short visit and 2 hours for the long.
1 should be enough
reviews/1/text:
The monastery and the gardens are worth the visit, so peaceful! 
Accessible by bus N°50, departures at 9:30, 11:30, 14:30, 16:30 from Agrolongo II. 2€ ticket, can be bought in the bus. Closed on Mondays.
reviews/2/text: What a fantastic place which no-one seems to have found.  Huge monastery with interesting history - you can see everything from the kitchens to the cells, toilets and the magnificent church.  Also beautiful grounds with a chapel and lake
reviews/3/text: A bit out of the way, but if you have the time, it can be a satisfying hour or so of your trip. Make no mistake, there are more spectacular places to see. So that’s why there was one car in the parking lot when we were there. Nonetheless, it’s got a nice church and some other rooms that are pretty good. Also, there are walls of fine tiles worth a gander. Finally, there is a certain serenity here that has a calming effect on the soul. We saw it because it was more or less on the way to Porto and so why not. If you have to go way out of your way to see it or you have limited time, I would pass this up.
reviews/3/title: Good, if you have the time
reviews/4/text: It is surely an extraordinary place to visit while in Braga. The visit exceeded all our expectations. We have been amazed with how the monastery has been rebuilt from the complete ruins. Not only the walls and decorations have been restored, but the atmosphere itself, so that while walking along its quiet long corridors, looking at lovingly restored cells and beautiful chapel, you can almost tangibly feel the presence of the long gone monks. We have been there in September and the gardens behind the monastery have been filled with the scent of the ripe grapes. Please do not miss this place when in Portugal. Do not forget to ask for the audio guide! After the visit, treat yourself with a nice food in the restaurant of the hotel next door.
reviews/5/text: cute place to visit and the detail in the craftsmanship was beautiful. The grounds are nice and the details on the woodwork on the chairs inside are great.
reviews/6/text: It is not often you get to visit a monastery in its entirety from the Church to the Chapter House, the cloisters, cells, refectory, Abbots quarters, guest accommodation and garden, you are free to wander. Although unoccupied since the late 1800s it has all been restored beautifully and there still is a feeling of calm and tranquility. The audio guide was very useful and guided us around all the features however there was also a leaflet in English which could have been used with a map. We were lucky when we visited as there were probably no more than 20 other people there and due to the vastness of the place it often felt like we had it to ourselves. We had heard the restaurant had closed down some time ago so were delighted to find the ladies belonging to a Holy Order had reopened it. The food was really lovely and the veal escalope had to be seen to be believed as it was enormous! All served by the ladies who did so with friendliness and good humour despite our limited Portuguese. This definitely was one of our highlights of the region.
reviews/6/title: A well kept secret with a lovely restaurant
reviews/7/text:
when i arrived at this monastery just before it opened at 10 i couldn't see 100 yards in front of me because of the mist,one hour later when it had lifted one gets to see this grand and imposing monastery in all it's glory and what a sight it is,you'll also find the inside is huge and with audio in portuguese and english on offer you'll not only get to see some of the marvels this monastery has to offer you'll also get to learn.
and do spend an hour or two in the gardens as some of the hidden gems you'll find are a real treat.
reviews/8/text:
I visit often the gardens and the park of Mosteiro de Tibães with my family. The área is very calm, and invites you for some meditation and to breath some fresh air through the path ways.

A great place not far from the city but where you can feel the country side and explore the forest  with kids or just by yourself.
reviews/8/title: A relaxing place very close to the city
reviews/9/text: Though the access to it may be a bit tricky, it's definitely worth the visit! The church, the gardens and the typical tile arts were surprising..
reviews/10/text: One of the jewels of Braga. Of you want to know how the monks lived and how was the life in closure and a humble lifestyle you should definitely see this. It's very old and also full of history. And you have lots of places with animals and nature. Great to relax
reviews/11/text:
This monastery absolutely exceeded our expectations! Low entrance fee, very friendly staff and interesten explanation through the audio guides!
Stunning renovation of an extraordinary location! One of the highlights of our trip to Portugal.
reviews/12/text: It doesn't matter if you are willing to take a stroll through the farm or to meditate for a while in a yoga class with a certified yoga master. The monastery is a rebuilt complex with a restaurant and a few rooms reserved for lodging. I love going there just to be in contact with nature. If you get lucky you can even visit some art or photography exhibitions or attend to a concert... all can happen in this amazing place. You can even spot a wedding ceremony.
reviews/13/text: A very large, recently restored complex that offers endless opportunities for knowledge. From those related to the history of monasteries in Portugal, from their fortunes to the misfortunes; to the constructive ones of a very complex complex, with parts dating to different ages and very different technologies; to the artistic products, produced in centuries. Then there is the chapter of the restoration works, recently concluded, with some very interesting ideas. In short, a visit that is worth doing. Beyond the organized tours, it is worth walking a bit around the inhabited rooms and watching walls, ceilings, floors: from the anti-seismic pombaline walls, to the cloaked ceilings ... At least, a pair of hours!
reviews/14/text: Spend time inside the monastery (rococo church...) beautifully restored, and then even more time in the garden. Two walks : the short one is 45 minutes, the long one is 1h30... If you can, sleep at the Hospedaria.
reviews/15/text: A big monastery. where you can walk around, visiting the cloisters, the rooms and cells, the kitchen,..and, specially the church, with beautiful barocco chapels, outstanding choir and organ. For the visit get the useful audio-guide,
reviews/15/title: A MOSTEIRO TO VISIT AND FEEL
reviews/16/text: It is a little bit difficult to get to the Mosteiro de Sao Martinho de Tibaes without a car but well worth a visit.  One could spend all day here wandering through the monastery and the beautiful gardens.
reviews/16/title: The highlight of my visit to Braga
reviews/17/text:
The Benedictine monastery of Tibães was the house mother of the monasteries of this order in Portugal and Brazil.
We had a excellent scientific restoration with garndes farmland and gardens, with lakes, ponds and fountains.
reviews/18/text: What a treat! I went out of season by bus from the centre of Braga. Made a special effort as it was closed on Monday when I wanted to go. The bus stop is just round the corner from the Ibis hotel and is a somewhat limited timetable but managed to squeeze in a good visit between buses although it took the best part of a whole morning it was worth it. Got the first bus out and got there as they were opening or perhaps they had seen me walking up the long green area in front the bus stop. I had the place to myself and it was exquisite and surprisingly large. I did get good vibes from the old corridors, the courtyards, the cloisters, the church and the little rooms but best of all was the garden where it was just so easy to imagine the monks working outside planting and hoeing. I was entranced at how close it must have been to what it used to be and dawdled there transfixed imagining the monastic activity. There was an unfortunate fire that burnt down the dining area/rectory which must have been tragic however they have made it into a new modern area for students and visitors to attend lectures and hold events. There was a video looping in a room which was a bit educational (in portuguese) but I suspect was made more for the funders of the renovations. The kitchen is worth a look eventhough it was altered in 18thC? it still exuded an aura of times past. There is a hotel here it seemed nice but I didn't stay there. The audio guide was helpful and informative and free (refundable deposit). This a jewel of a building and  helped me transport myself to mediaval times especially the small garden areas but I imagined I could hear the cartwheels in the courtyard and see the monks moving ghostly, serenely and silently around this large and suprsingly enchanting building. Get there if you can you are not likely to regret it.
reviews/19/text:
a whole day it's not enough to visit and see all the beauties of this ancient Monastery.
You will find history and will be able to enjoy the gardens and forest which surrounds the great Benedictine Monastery.
subcategory_ranking: #2 of 119 things to do in Braga

reviews/0/text:
Sanctuary of Our Lady of Sameiro!
First time visiting and really passionate for this Sanctuar!
Nice view
reviews/1/text: Beautiful church and surrounding. Great photos especially as we had a clear blue sunny day. Definitely worth a stop. Views of Braga are amazing from here.
reviews/2/text: You will get some great pictures here. The exterior of the church is imposing. You will take quite a few pictures of it from different angles, because it looks good every which way you turn. Then the views of the surrounding area are excellent, taking advantage of the mount on which the church was constructed.    The church, itself, is a bit of a letdown. It’s not bad, but it’s not tremendously impressive inside. I would say, rather bland would describe it best. A site this bold deserves a truly majestic interior. It needs to be inspiring, one where you want to look around in awe. The church at Bom Jesus, nearby, far more successfully achieves this mating of environment and building. If you go to Bom Jesus, by all means come here, too. If you go here, you would be an idiot to not also visit the marvelous Bom Jesus, with its magnificent and mindbendingly long series of staircases down the mountain, perhaps the number one reason I wanted to visit northern Portugal. Looking at pictures on the internet, as great as they look, do not do it even a semblance of justice. My sky high expectations were not only met, but way surpassed. And if you visit the Douro Valley and you have the time, go see the similar Santuario Nossa Senhora dos Remedios in Lamego. It’s out of the way, but the drive up is fantastic and there is also a pretty good small cathedral there. Worth the time and effort.
reviews/3/text: One of the most gorgeous and unpredictable Portugal beauties! The breathtaking panorama of Braga opens from Sanctuary's windows, so you can admire both Sanctuary's decoration and the city on which hills it's located.
reviews/4/text: An open space with a church that was visited by the pope. Beautiful place, quiet and the halls used for religious activities are worth seeing. View of Braga from that height is also memorable. Pity that this place is not as much known as the boun Gesu church. Only half an hour away. Not to be missed
reviews/5/text: Beautiful cathedral overlooking Braga. Very symbolic church in Portugal.  Must witness the stunning sun set. Transport is required, as the church is 15mins from the city centre.
reviews/6/text: The idea that people pilgrimage here today and for 100’s of years before is amazing. It’s pretty up there and worth seeing!
reviews/7/text:
Amazing church located high on a hilltop and visible for miles around.  Dedicated to Mary, the church occupies a large plot of land and its gleaming white dome is its key feature.

There is no cost to enter.

The church hosted Pope John Paul II and there are several items of historical interest.  If you are visiting Bom Jesus, this church is quite close and worth a look too.  It’s not as old as some of the other churches but it’s grand scale is quite impressive.
reviews/8/text:
Wonderful  Basilica , so quiet and tranquil. Amazing ceramics.
A view to remember.
Well worth the visit.
reviews/9/text: Sanctuary of Our Lady of Sameiro is a very big church located about 5km far from Bom Jesus do Monte, near Braga, in the North of Portugal. It was built in 19th Century and it is now the second important Marian place in Portugal after Fatima, so it is a place of pilgrimage. Really, the main building is big and very beautiful, and the views of Braga and surroundings are very nice. Very interesting place. Very beautiful especially in the sunset.
reviews/9/title: very beautiful Marian sanctuary and very nice views
reviews/10/text: If you’re looking for an excellent view of the city this is where you had to go. There’s also an impressive church at the top. It’s not an older church it’s actually quite new but it’s still very impressed all the same. There’s also parks and trails All the way up to the hill.
reviews/11/text: Lovely place for a stroll, the panoramas are absolutely stunning. What we liked is that it wasn’t as crowded as Bom Jesus do Monte, we though of it being actually even better.
reviews/12/text: We visited the beautiful church on the hill early in the morning on the next day after we went to the Bom Jesus do Monte. And it was good so – we could define the impressions. The fog and emptiness made this place mysterious and magnificent.  The atmosphere in the church was calming and invited to sit down and think of …
reviews/13/text: This large church is located near Bom Jesus, and one can walk from there in about half an hour. This sanctuary also has a staircase, but much less impressive than the one in Bom Jesus (and there is no lift, so much fewer tourists). However, the church here is nicer and well worth a visit. From nearby in the village one can take the bus back to Braga, or carry on to the 3rd sanctuary.
reviews/13/title: nice church on top of a not very impressive staircase
reviews/14/text: This is a fascinating interesting place to visit.  We highly recommended this place on the day we visited it was raining and a service was taking place. We walked around to appreciate the building and the views magnificent.
reviews/15/text:
Not far outside Braga.
Walk up the steps (maybe 100 - 150) to the top for great views. Wonderful church buildings - very historic. Huge open spaces around and beautiful gardens.
Cafe, restaurant, gift shop.
Very different and quieter than Bom Jesus which is only 10 mins drive away. We loved this place.
reviews/16/text: This is very close to the centre and worth visiting, no entrance fees but there are steps to climb which may be difficult for some. When we went inside, the service was going on and we could not take pictures.
reviews/17/text: I did not enter the sanctuary but it really is a masterpiece. The view from here is better than the good jesus from Braga
reviews/18/text:
The church and surrounding grounds are beautiful. The church from a distance is majestic. Not much to see. View is gorgeous 
Clean rest room facilities.
reviews/19/text: I think many people forego Sameiro, in favour of Bom Jesus. Perhaps it isn't as spectacular but it's worth a visit nonetheless. It faces the same direction, west, so read my review on Bom Jesus for photography advice. If you catch a bus up, hang on to the ticket, you may be in time to reuse it again to go down - see my photo of the bus ticket. Do walk down the steps, the view of the church is spectacular from below. See my photos to get an idea - they were taken on my mobile as my camera batteries went dead - it must have switched itself on and off without my realising it. :(
reviews/19/user/user_location/name: Las Palmas de Gran Canaria, Spain
subcategory_ranking: #4 of 119 things to do in Braga

address: Braga Norte 920, Braga 4710-923 Portugal
name: Palacio do Raio
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Braga And Guimaraes Private Tour From Porto
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Cosmopolitan Braga - Full Day - from Porto
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Best spots of Braga walking tour
ranking: #6 of 119 things to do in Braga
ranking_subcategory: #6 of 119 things to do in Braga
reviews/0/text: It's a beautiful edifice and pictures don't do it justice. Besides it's pretty difficult to catch a moment without a car or pedestrian spoiling the view.
reviews/1/text: this is more about taking photos than the building its ok just for 5 minutes as its close to other attractions
reviews/2/text: Another great example of baroque in Braga: nice mix of grey and blue. Check opening times before going there.
reviews/3/text: Palácio do Raio, who is also referred as “Casa do Mexicano”, is located in the Rua do Raio, no. 400, in the parish of São José de São Lázaro. It is one of the most notable buildings of civil architecture in the city, in the Baroque style of João. as a whole, giving priority to the most unprotected and promoting quality of life, assuming the commitment to support the most disadvantaged in the practice of the 14 Works of Mercy.
reviews/4/text: An interesting and attractive building. Whilst we had not originally expected to enjoy the interior exhibitions these did help put some of the history of the city into perspective. Well labelled - with English captions.
reviews/5/text: I loved the archtecture. Absolutely beautiful facade and I totally recommend to vist at least outside.
reviews/6/text: This is a beautiful 18th century building, very well preserved/restored, one of the many surprises in this beautiful and interesting city
reviews/7/text: The design and the colours of this building are simply amazing. The work that was put into it to match the tiles, doors, windows and railings is just perfect. There isn't much inside, but you must walk by to see the braga design work.
reviews/8/text: The Palacio do Raio is in the centre of Braga, Portugal. The palace was built in 1754 and is the best example in Braga of Braga civil architecture. The blue in the building is stunning. It costs a few Euros to enter but there is not much to see inside. The outside though is well worth a visit.
reviews/9/text:
Overall, it's unique! The design is unique. 

You have to pay to get in! I haven't, so I cannot say anything about that.

But it's a go-go.
reviews/10/text: Palacio do Raio has a beautiful outside, but nothing special inside and it costs 2 Euros. Not recommend for paying for the visit
reviews/11/text: The Palacio do Raio is one of the best examples of Portuguese Baroque architecture. What may not be immediately apparent is that is was designed  - and used - as a hospital. The interior is almost as ornate as the exterior. In my opinion, this is the main reason for visiting Braga.
reviews/12/text:
We stopped by on a Sunday afternoon, but unfortunately the palace is closed on Sundays and Mondays. We were only able to admire it from the outside.
As far as I could see, it’s not very big, you might need an hour or two to see the inside.
reviews/13/text: The Palácio do Raio or House of the Mexican is a Baroque-era Palace in Downtown Braga. It is an example of the late Baroque, early Rococo style of decoration by Portuguese architect André Soares. It Belongs to the Church and is a Museum now.
reviews/14/text: Palacio do Raio is an 18th century Baroque style building. It's a lovely residence, fit for anyone who could afford it! It is an example of the opulent past. The most striking feature is the facade which is covered in blue azulejo tiles. Absolutely fantastic! The balcony, too, is a great feature. Inside there is a beautiful staircase and the granite floors are striking. There are a few artworks and other objects inside, but no furniture or other furnishings, which is a pity.  The whole building is built from fine-grained granite and you can't help admiring the fine work that has gone into all of this. However the outside of the building is probably worth admiring much more than the interior.  Worth visiting if you are nearby.
reviews/15/text: The palace is very interesting on the outside with its many azuléjos   The inside, unlike Biscainhos is not furnished. Some of the rooms are interesting but without furnishings it doesn’t give you the same sense of history.
reviews/16/text: This striking blue tiled palace is a great free attraction and is a definite must see when in Braga, the beautiful blue tiles on the outside are amazing to look at whilst the inside is a bit more understated and photos inside are prohibited. Great free attraction
reviews/17/text: This is one of the most beautiful baroque buildings of the city of Braga, recently recovered, in the center of the city.
reviews/18/text: We did not go inside this palace although entrance is free but stayed outside and admired the fantastic blue tiles that adorn the outside walls of the building. They are truly beautiful and make for a wonderful photo reminder when you return home. It’s a pity that they allow cars to park in front of the building.
reviews/19/text: I must’ve missed something during my visit to Braga. The outside of this tiny Blue Tiled Palace is beautiful, but the inside wasn’t too impressive for me. Taking pictures inside is prohibited, I believe my entrance was free. Definitely nice to see if you visit Braga.
subcategory_ranking: #6 of 119 things to do in Braga

photo/caption:
Tulipeiro da Virgínia, monumento natural dos Jardins do Museu dos Biscainhos.

ranking: #10 of 119 things to do in Braga
ranking_subcategory: #10 of 119 things to do in Braga
reviews/0/text:
Jardins da Casa dos Biscainhos is a great spot for someone who wants to take a few pictures.
We will be back here
reviews/1/text: It's a beautiful garden, with a lot of potencial for other activities that could better dinamize the space.
reviews/2/text: Jardim da Casa dos Biscainhos is just so lovely. The Gardens are really beautiful and obviously extremely well maintained. You enter and find yourself in another world, quiet, peaceful and restful. The residence is another lovely building and there are so many beautiful objects to admire.
reviews/3/text: You begin your visit of Biscainhos by viewing the gardens which are very pretty when the Camélia trees are in bloom. Then a guide takes you through each room of the palace which contains furnishings appropriate to the time period. Well worth a visit.
reviews/4/text:
Nice to go to and rest a bit. Gardens are free.
Average but if you have the time... why not?
If you have more time visit the house (pay 2 euros).
reviews/5/text: Lovely gardens, very quiet and peaceful. It's free! And a great place to relax a bit. I definitely recommend it.
reviews/6/text: Lovely house and gardens. Excellent guided tour of the house only at specific times. Beautiful interior and a garden to linger in.
reviews/7/text: This is a peaceful garden at the back of the casa dos biscainhos and well worth visiting. Some of the structures are closed but even on a cold wet day it was very attractive
reviews/8/text: Really lovely gardens behind the mansion.  Our visit was free.  Beautifully landscaped with some charming statues.  Good photo op.  Old world charm.
reviews/9/text: It's really worth visiting the museum that allows you to visit the house and gardens. It's in the city centre and cheap.
reviews/10/text: There are flowers here year round. It is a lovely place for a stroll or even a great place to sit and read up on the attractions in Braga. It is very well maintained and the colors can be stunning. Near the casa, inside the wrought iron fencing is part of an old Roman archway.You can get a very nice picture through the fence, if you are lucky, the roses will be blooming too.
reviews/11/text: Placed almost in the heart of the city and very easily missed this gardens are a real gem, very nice for a sunny afternoon spent in the middle of a little heart of nature, combined with a visit to the Museum makes it for a refreshing afternoon.
reviews/12/text:
This is where we stayed for a rest after our morning walk. We were looking and inquiring how to get a ride in going to Sanctuario Bom Jesus. Everyone was nice and helpful. 

Lovely garden and shady cool atmosphere.
reviews/13/text: We visited it as part of the house tour so I don't know if you can visit it separately (cheaper) but it's a beautiful garden
reviews/14/text: A great place to visit both during summer and in the winter and there is no entrance fee.. it's a shame they closed a little early in the evening
reviews/14/title: A great resting place in between tours
reviews/15/text: Loved this garden, you can get cool pictures here. You can imagine how crazy it must been to live here in past times.
reviews/16/text:
Well maintained with some good specimen trees. Not a lot flowering at the end of September but as it s free I will visit again in the Spring. 
While we were there a tour group came in and were done and out while we were still there.
We didn't go in the museum although did sneak in at the end of the tour to look at the kitchens which were interesting.
reviews/17/text: This is a beautiful garden in the Biscainhos Museum, in the center of Braga. The garden it's in barroco style, with many old trees.
reviews/18/text: If you are exploring the city it is well worth walking through the gardens and exploring this site. Well maintained.
reviews/19/text: The Garden is part of/hidden behind the Biscainhos Museum. It is at three levels with mature tress, flowers ponds and fountains which sadly were not working when we were there. Ornaments, shady paths, and a summer house all add to the experience.summer house
subcategory_ranking: #10 of 119 things to do in Braga

address: Rua Dom Diogo de Sousa 127, Braga 4700-422 Portugal
name: Arco da Porta Nova
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Braga and Guimarães Tour with Lunch from Porto
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Braga and Guimarães Full Day Private Tour from Porto
offer_group/offer_list/2/title: Braga Half-Day Private Tour from Porto

ranking: #8 of 119 things to do in Braga
ranking_subcategory: #8 of 119 things to do in Braga
reviews/0/text: To be honest there is nothing special about the arc and the door. It is a tourist attraction. You can just go and cost and take the moment.
reviews/1/text:
What we can say about Arco da Porta Nova ...
It is a good place to take a few photos and ejoy that time
reviews/2/text: It is on the way to/from Braga's train station and on a major pedestrian street. Each side is of particular interest.
reviews/3/text: Impressive arch through which you pass to get into the old town. Good as a photo opportunity and also as ameeting/orientationpoint.
reviews/3/title: Impressive and useful as a meeting point
reviews/4/text: Such an iconic monument and a meeting place for most tours to Braga. Apparently this gate gave rise to many sayings in Portuguese and Spanish such as if you leave a door or window open, you will hear "You must be from Braga" coz the this monument does not have a door to close. Also, admonishments such as "I will send you to the lower parts of Braga" (this monument is at the lower part of Braga) arose out of this monument as the lower parts of Braga at the time were seedy. A piece of history!
reviews/5/text:
The “Arco da Porta Nova” was one of the doors in the city walls, torn down in the year 1512, at the time of the Archbishop of Braga, D. Diogo de Sousa.
Its current appearance dates back to the year 1772, at the initiative of Archbishop D. Gaspar de Bragança, with a project by the architect from Braga, André Soares, at a historical moment when the city broke the old walls, expanding.
It has been classified as a National Monument since the year 1910. Next to it is a medieval tower, belonging to the Fernandina wall, and practically covered by the houses. Anyhow a nice attraction to see during your visit of the historical part of the city of Braga.
reviews/5/title: Visiting the historical part of Braga.
reviews/6/text: Very nice entrance to the center of the city. Is the first thing you see when you arrive from the train station.
reviews/7/text: At the end or at the beginning of the De Souto street, it all depends from which side you come is this nice Arc to stroll underneath.
reviews/8/text: My first of the old town when walking up from the train station was this lovely decorative arch. It spans the narrow road attached on both sides to elegant buildings. It certainly lets you know you are entering a beautiful part of town as the historic centre is indeed a gem.
reviews/9/text:
Looks nice
Not huge 
But shows way into old town street
Braga looks interesting 
Cheap place to visit and live apparently
reviews/10/text: The Arch of the New Gate is a few hundred metres from the Braga Train Station. Thus when you walk to the Braga town centre from the train station it is the first tourist attraction you see. The gate is the entrance, and part of the old wall, to Old Town Braga. It’s architecture is beautiful and a good welcome to your Braga visit experience.
reviews/11/text: It's at the doors of the city. You won't miss it. It's part of of the old walls! It gets you right on track to go to downtown. Take it as your pointing-guide.
reviews/11/title: You won't come to Braga without seeing this monument!
reviews/12/text: You know when you have happened upon this landmark, helps get you oriented on the tourist map and guide you to main street.
reviews/13/text: Part of the old entrance to Old Town. I found it interesting and a great marker when with a group. A must see if you are down town.
reviews/14/text: This arch is perhaps the best symbol of Braga's welcoming spirit. It was the first time a city wall had a permanently open door. Close to the end of the afternoon, walk down Rua do Souto and admire the golden reflex caused by the sunset in this monument. Admire it for a while and turn right, getting into Tíbias de Braga pastry. Choose anything. All items are excellent.
reviews/15/text: The Arch of the New Gate is a great entrance to the old city of Braga.  The front side is more decorative than the back side.  There are many restaurants just past the entrance and down the street on the left.
reviews/16/text: We had a meal in one of the restaurants near by when we saw the arc! Beautiful addition to our walk in town! Nice photo stop!
reviews/17/text:
The Arch was well worth visiting. We walked through the arch and along 
into the city centre. It was a lovely place to see.
reviews/18/text:
Didn't know that there was a gate here.
Make sure you check out both sides as they are different. 
In very good condition and marks the entry to the old town.
reviews/19/text: This entrance, the only one remaining, is quite impressive, and well worth the walk there, in this small historic town. There is no entrance fee, and cannot be climbed either).
reviews/19/title: Nice old entrance gate to a nice historic city
subcategory_ranking: #8 of 119 things to do in Braga

address: Rua do Souto, Braga 4700-329 Portugal
name: Rua do Souto
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Braga & Guimarães Private Tour (All Inclusive)
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Guimarães, Braga & Barcelos Tour
ranking: #9 of 119 things to do in Braga
ranking_subcategory: #9 of 119 things to do in Braga
reviews/0/text: The most important street of the city. Pedestrian street full of shops and restaurants. Walk by and enjoy the vibe.
reviews/1/text: Just a great palce to stroll around and see the old (and some new) shops. This street has history and you see that.
reviews/2/text: I'm not into shopping and it's certainly not why I was in Braga, but nevertheless I found Ruo do Souto brimful of energy and life. Lots of shops obviously, not all high street labels but plenty of local stores too which is good to see. Pedestrianised so good for a stroll to see the beating heart of retail Braga life.
reviews/3/text:
It's the central street in the historical center of Braga. Pleasent to see all the history written on its walls and pathways. 

Although, you gotta be careful at night. There are chances of robbery between 2 a.m. and 6 a.m.

Overall, it connects all points of Braga's downtown.
reviews/4/text: Rua do Souto is a shopping and pedestrian street located in the old town of Braga, a city in the Northern region in Portugal. It is a nice street to walk, see shops, relax or only take a coffee or drink something. The typical pedestrian street in a city.
reviews/5/text: This is one of the main streets on a Old Town Braga.  There are many restaurants of all kinds and a few souvenir shops.  Hard to miss this street if on Braga.
reviews/6/text: Rua do Souto is one of the streets we wandered around during our one day visit to Braga. It's a historic street with its origins going as far back as the 15th century. It has undergone a few transformations since then! Now it's the main shopping street of the city and you can find anything you wish here! We found it quite pleasant without the oppressive numbers of visitors you encounter in bigger cities. It also connects to the beautiful Praca Republica.
reviews/7/text: Just beside the cathedral this street is closed to traffic. It contains many interesting shops and good restaurants. It has a nice historic feel to it. Some good prices in the shops compared to other tourist cities in Portugal. Leads into the Praça República
reviews/8/text: Great street to walk along with many great shops to look inside and also cafes to grab refreshments, entry to the street at the bottom is via the beautiful archway which is worth going to just see this.
reviews/9/text: This is the main shopping street in Braga with many small and large shops and cafes. It is made for a slow stroll to fully enjoy. If you don’t want to shop have a coffee and cake at A. Brasileira Restaurant as this will add to the experience. There are churches of course to see but this is essentially a commercial street which will eventually lead to the main Plaza.
reviews/10/text:
The shopping street in Braga. A must see in the city.
Full of shops and cafes. Close to the cathedral and rectory of the university.
reviews/11/text:
Very nice a more cosier feeling that the rua in Porto with shops, cafe etc on either side.

If you are coming from train station go right and it leads you directly to the arch which is the start of Rua Do Souto.

It goes for about 3 blocks and does have a good atmosphere to it.
reviews/12/text: A typical commercial street and with a few traditional stores. It's nice to take a walk and enjoy the surroundings but don't expect to see a huge bunch of local stores, unfortunately.
reviews/13/text:
This street is full of shops and restaurants . It connects to arco so porto  nova on one side and a large square with fountains  on the other. Can be walked in about 10 minutes. 
I personally  found the squares of Braga far more pleasant to stroll.
reviews/14/text: if you want to find some nice and interesting shops, this is the place to visit, many local people and not many tourists
reviews/15/text: Enjoyed walking through the streets of Braga, lots of small shops, historical interest opening up to a lovely square
reviews/16/text: Pedestrian only are and the main route from the station up to the Republic Plaza. It makes for a nice stroll and there is a good mixture of shops - personally I would ignore the typical tourist traps selling souvenirs but it depends what you are looking for.
reviews/17/text: Pleasant pedestrian street with shopping, eating and drinking.  In the middle of the old city with tourist sites  around.
reviews/18/text: Rua do Souto located in Braga Portugal, is a collection of interesting stores and restaurants in the shopping district.  It is a mostly pedestrian area with vehicles not allowed except for the odd one making a delivery.
reviews/19/text:
Rua do Souto is the most famous street in Braga.
It connects two landmarks of the city: "Arco da Porta Nova" one of the ancient points of entry in the city and the "Praça da República" named the city center, with it's fountain and famous coffee shops. It's a non traffic street with lots of small shops, restaurants and coffee places.
subcategory_ranking: #9 of 119 things to do in Braga

address: Largo Engenheiro Carlos Amarante 11, Braga 4700-308 Portugal
name: Igreja de Santa Cruz
offer_group/offer_list/0/title: Braga and Guimarães Tour with Lunch from Porto
offer_group/offer_list/1/title: Braga Half-Day Private Tour from Porto
ranking: #12 of 119 things to do in Braga
ranking_subcategory: #12 of 119 things to do in Braga
reviews/0/text: It is located in one of the popular squares of Braga. Good attraction, nice ambiance and perfect architecture. If you are in Braga, a must see.
reviews/1/text: One of the buildings making Praca da Republica so  beautiful. The interior is also astonishing, with amazing decorations and a lot of gold everywhere.
reviews/2/text: The architecture is amazing and mostly the facade. Is a "must" if you visit Braga and the entrance is free
reviews/3/text: Probably another beautiful Braga church but there are renovations going on, not much to see inside as most is covered in plastic sheet
reviews/4/text: The beautiful square where the church is located was perfectly manicured and the greens and golds of the flowers complimented the external beauty of this church. Inside, the gold and baroque designs are something that must be seen. The details are impressive. The location, the design and artwork make this church one great package to visit.
reviews/5/text:
This is the first time I've ever been in a church at the same time that the gold gilting has actually been going on. The smell of it is incredibly pungent. 
Anyway, I sont think I've ever seen any interior so golden! The altarpiece has to be seen to be believed. I've done my best with the pictures for you all!
Free to enter and beautifully serene, there are lovely side altars too. It's a must see if you are in the centre of Braga,.
That altarpiece - seriously. I cant even...
reviews/6/text:
Work of art. Both the inside and out are a delicious sight for our eyes. You dont have to be religious to like or appreciate how much history is contained within church. The perfection and detail are present wherever you look.
It's a must to visit if you go to Braga.
reviews/7/text: To pair with Basílica dos Congregados, in my opinion its obverse, and equally stunning for the magnificent outside front - with its many roman inscriptions, carved symbols and stunning backdrop (especially at night) in one of the city's main plazas.
reviews/8/text: In Braga, there are a large number of churches, the most famous ones are definitely the Bom Jesus and the Se, this is a normal one with beautiful outside, but also nothing that special.
reviews/8/title: One of the churches in Braga
reviews/9/text: One of Braga's many baroque churches with gilded granite altars, located at Largo Carlos Amarante, in the center of the city.
reviews/9/title: One of Braga's many baroque churches
reviews/10/text: If you do the very interesting Braga baroque itinerary, you should enter this church located in the center, on a beautiful square. All altars depict steps of the last days of Christ and are adorned with beautiful gold carved wood frames. Enjoy!
reviews/11/text: Santa Cruz is another of the many beautiful churches in Braga. And there are quite a few of them! This one supposedly holds a piece of the holy Cross, hence the name... The facade of the building is quite stunning and so is the interior of the church. It's absolutely worth stopping by and going inside, even for a few minutes.
reviews/12/text: There is a beautiful church on almost every block in old Braga. This church is located neat the large Braga sign. It is worth stopping in for a moment. Closed until after 3:00 I waited to go in but honestly can’t tell the difference between this one and many of the others. All are beautiful
reviews/13/text:
This really is a hidden gem, somewhat away from the main hustle and bustle of Braga and other main attractions this really is a must see.

The outside is lovely but once you step inside it really is something else such a stunning place of worship. 

Incredibly detail and so many different features that really have to be seen.

This church sums Braga up lovely from the outside and simply magical from the inside.
reviews/14/text: It is in someway an oddity in its position in the town. It has a beautiful interior with magnificent arches. The exterior is also interesting with its two cockerels on the walls. It has an interesting claim in history not least its claim to have a piece of the cross from Christ’s crucifixion. We are all waiting for the carbon dating test!
reviews/15/text: This church is majestic for the size of Braga. The facade is remarkable and the interiors are also very very beautiful. I would strongly suggest anyone to see this.
reviews/16/text:
A magnificent temple that is the epitome of Braga: a church dedicated to the Holy Cross of Christ.
In the predominant local Barroque style, it exhibits a symbolic richness in its faça de that continues (even if on a smaller scale) on the inside.
It gives the "real name" to the square, whilst it's builder/architect gives it the official one (Carlos Amarante, a local Barroque master)
reviews/17/text: This is one of the numerous churches in the city of Braga to visit. The façade is very intriguing since there are two cockerels there. It is probably due to the dedication of the church to the Holy Cross. During Holy Week ceremonies a procession is held which is worth seeing.
reviews/17/title: One of the many wonderful churches of Braga to visit
reviews/18/text: If you pass by and a lot of people are looking puzzlingly at the facade... they are looking for cocks (as in male chicken - it is a church!). If you don't find two, you won't get married, or so the legend goes... do look at the wind vanes on top of the towers, since they are quite original (no, not the cocks). This church is called "Holly Cross" since it is supposed to hold a little piece of the cross in which Jesus was crucified (and the one which, if you join all the pieces supposedly in churches all over the world, is about 3 tons). Anyway, it is a nice church with great bells and church organs.
reviews/19/text: Arquitetura fantástica e o interior parece tudo ouro. Não paga para entrar, é uma igreja onde acontecem missas normalmente.. Inclusive entrei no meio da missa mas discretamente bati foto. Lindo dentro

reviews/0/text: The entrance is only 2 Euros if you want to see the Catedral. The whole sight is 5 Euros. It is an amazing architecture and sight and is strongly recommended.
reviews/1/text:
Amazing Church Sé de Braga.
With a Nice Architecture and Painting. Very well done.
Nice photos and nice time expended
reviews/2/text: the church really has the wow factor was the highlight of my trip to braga its a must even if you are not into churches make an exeption and vist this mastery
reviews/3/text: This church is beautiful and unique in its history. It is the oldest cathedral in Portugal, being founded even before the establishment of Portugal as a country. You can find important tombs inside if you participate in the guided, which I highly recommend, since it will give you access to the private chapels and the area where the religious leaders meet. Our tour was given in English (Portuguese was also possible of course). For 5 euros, you can see the cathedral, chapels, and museum.
reviews/4/text: If angels and baroque don't put you off, don't miss the Cathedral. Amazing work. The visit of the Chapels and Coro Alto shouldn't be missed.
reviews/5/text:
22/6/22 - Wednesday late afternoon

We three middle aged Brits were staying in town three nights and this was on our list. One of us is against church or cathedral entrance fees so we split up. At around 3:30pm I bought the full €5 ticket whilst my friend bought just the Cathedral €2 ticket in the side street entrance to the cathedral complex. My ticket included a guided tour of the chapels and upper choir, scheduled at 4pm.

We both had a walk around the cathedral which is quite plain with the statues on stretchers for decorating and hauling around town during Santa Semana. The organ was the most impressive thing in the church though. My friend left and I waited for the tour.

A group of mainly Portuguese gathered and a guide took us through the complex to a series of very interesting chapels of various ages. Tiled walls, pigment decorated walls, tombs, a very wrinkly but undecomposed archbishop (it's a miracle apparently), florid walls, turkish influences, mum&dad statues above tombs, miracle fruits....

I was the only English speaker there so the guide patiently repeated everything personally to me in English whilst an apprentice listened in.

Up we went a few flights of stairs into the upper choir which was amazing! Two identical working organs were at the alter end of the rows of named seats of the choir. A 'clock' at the end was set at 3pm as that's when Christ was nailed to the cross.

Later we three rejoined and wandered round the free parts of the cathedral complex including the archbishop tombs and a chapel with lots of wax figures of heads, legs and arms....a local custom?

Altogether a very good value excursion, especially with the one to one commentary! 

The managers just really need to get rid of that rubbish euro paladin bin in the courtyard though…..
reviews/5/title: Great organ, good value combi ticket, plain interior but undressed statues ready for santa semana
reviews/6/text: Impressive facade and portal but it does seem to have been hemmed in somewhat bylater additions. Internal monuments are grand enough to be impressive without being oppressively so and detracting from the magnificence of the building itself.
reviews/6/title: Exterior slightly pinched in but a glorious interior.
reviews/7/text: The Cathedral of Braga was consecrated in 1089, about 54 years before Portugal became a country! As is the case in many historical buildings, renovation and rebuilding through the centuries result in a variety of different architectural styles. Today’s church is a mix of Gothic, Manueline and Baroque features. There is a nominal charge to visit the church, and it will cost you a few more euros on top of that for the chapels, high choir, and museum. Go for it! You can view the high choir with its elaborate gilt wood carving and double organs from the nave, and then you’ll wish you were up close. The Chapel of Glory and the Chapel of Kings, both dating to the 1300s, are equally stunning.
reviews/8/text: Extremely gorgeous Roman heritage! Outside and inside decorations of this cathedral are so fabulous! Highly recommend visiting!
reviews/9/text:
The Braga Cathedral was built on the foundations of an old market or Roman temple, and the walls of a later Paleo-Christian basilica.
Its best documented history dates back to the work of the first bishop, D. Pedro de Braga, and corresponds to the restoration of the Episcopal and this in the year 1070, of which few traces are preserved.
In the year 1128, a building with five chapels at the apse was started, which were partially destroyed by the earthquake in the year 1135.
In the year 1268 the works were still not completed. On the outbuildings of the former house of the “Cabido”, built at the beginning of the 18th century by Archbishop D. Rodrigo de Moura Teles, currently stands the Braga Cathedral Treasure-Museum.
In the 20th century, the tomb of the religious and stigmatized Sister Maria Estrela Divina, a center of great popular devotion, was placed next to the cloisters. His collection of Sacred Relics became famous, including the piece of a Mantle of the Holy Virgin Mary, in the Chapel of Relics. There are chests containing the bones of many saints, and the so-called Holy Ark is legendary, whose contents will be remarkable, and went out in procession in the past, on days of solemn feasts.
It has been classified as a National Monument since the year 1910.
reviews/10/text:
As the proverb says, Porto works, Braga prays, Coimbra studies, and Lisbon gets the money. Se de Braga and it's amazing museum proves at least the part of praying. An impressive building, with impressive history and a huge collection of objects and stories relevant for the religious character of Braga city.

The visit includes a guided part (conducted by a young lady, prepared to answer questions and tell interesting stories) and a you're on your own part (quite OK, as the exhibits have enough information in English). It is well worth the small entrance fee.
reviews/11/text: We enjoyed viewing the architecture and the vast contrast between the original Romanesque and later Baroque features. We were less impressed by the museum - largely unlabelled items - difficult to understand full significance/story.
reviews/12/text: Nice architecture. This church is in a street that is usually full of restaurants and shops but luckilñy almost everything was closed when i visited.
reviews/13/text: You are about to visit the oldest Roman Catholic Cathedral Church in Portugal! The "Sé Catedral de Braga" dates from the 11th century and has seen, along the years, many additions and restorations. Naturally, characteristics of different architectural styles are found: Romanesque, Gothic, Baroque, Moorish and Manueline! Visit the church, check its facade, main nave, chapels, baptismal font, high choir, organs, cloisters, awesome gilted engravings and traditional Portuguese tiles. And if time is not a constraint, do not miss its adjoining museum, completely renovated in 2007 to house the Cathedral's magnificent religious art treasure! Enjoy!
reviews/13/title: 900 years of history and religious life!
reviews/14/text:
Braga is so special with so much history. Loads of Roman buildings,,actually whole city is build on top of the Roman City
I was very impressed with the Cathedral, especially is wooden carved ceiling, the courtyard with Roman statues, with a Museum where you can see Cardinals outfits.
It also has an area where you'l find its a resting place for Cardinals
reviews/14/title: A relic with an interesting museum
reviews/15/text:
It is the oldest cathedral in Portugal. Personally I liked very little both inside and outside. Few things to see and the exhibition path badly organized. Only positive note is the beautiful main facade decorated with a large number of statues.

If you would like to see my tips just go to the following link: https://www.tripadvisor.it/Trips/92555137/The%20northern%20region%20of%20Portugal
reviews/15/title: Only positive note is the beautiful main facade
reviews/16/text: It is a Se, but the Murials made of the blue & white tiles are beeuatiful, Especially the walls upstairs. The entrance fee is 2 Euro, so it's ok. There are many rooms to discover. So see for yourself.
reviews/17/text:
It's not often a specific church's beginnings can be attributed to Saint James.  Or that Saint Peter of Rates was resurrected to be Braga's first bishop.  This church has a varied collection throughout history, with the first thing we noticed was the old smell.  The original structure dates from the 1000s, replacing a prior structure. 
 The main chapel from the 1300s.  The organ from the 1700s.  And a lot of history in between.  Most churches seem to have a specific theme or focus; in my opinion not this one, other than history itself.
reviews/18/text:
The Cathedral in Braga is nowhere near as ornate as some of the other churches and from the outside looks more like a fortress than a place of worship.

Individual entry fees are charged for almost all areas except the courtyard and some tombs or you can pay €5 to visit the entire church.

Personally I found it a bit underwhelming although it might have been more interesting if I had been prepared to pay the €5.
reviews/19/text:
I really likes the Sè in Braga, right in the heart of the old town. For €2 you can visit the cloisters, crypt and the cathedral itself. For €3 you can visit the museum but I didnt add that particular option.
The Cathedral is cavernous as you'd expect but still retains a homely and welcoming feel. I loved the banners hanging from the walls between the windows and the unbelievably intricate and decorative organ at the back of the nave. The altar is simple, but it has gorgeous stained glass windows flanking stand beautifully carved chorister chaurs.
Most if the visit will be spent at the gold gilted organ I suspect. It really has to be seen to be believed, as beautiful an organ as you ever will see with a beautifully painted ceiling above it.

It has a fountain which was dry on my visit,  and a bandstand with grassy areas which the locals lounge on while eating lunch. reviews/8/text: This square is full of flowers, it's very secure and clean. Children playing around some people selling portuguese chellnuts, and close have several other small square that have artists playing, coffee shops all around and, of course, is full of department stores.
reviews/9/text: The Praça da Republica is one of the main squares in Braga, Portugal. It is a garden type square with buildings around it - some very lovely buildings. There are monuments, fountains and churches lining the square. It is nice but nothing special.

(See also Bragashopping)
reviews/13/text: This is a nice place to come and sit outside and have a cup of coffee or a pastry and enjoy the views of the pretty gardens and the cute town.

Nice place to sit for a bit and relax.

reviews/18/text: Praca da Republica is a great public space. It's large-ish, and the area around is like a long, stretched out park, full of greenery and beautiful colourful flowers. They take care of this area, as we observed a number of workers tending to the plants. A great place to wander through, to visit shops and do some shopping, and to sit down at one of the local cafes or restaurants, have a coffee or a meal, or both, and just watch the world go by.
reviews/19/text: A nice large open air park in the middle of the historic city. Most streets are narrow but the Praça is wide and open with gardens and fountains. It makes a good place to meet. ave da Liberdade à main thoroughfare and shopping streets begins at the Praça and has gardens all down its length. Everything is very central to here.
